urn:contentItem:6GMP-6CX3-RY48-4344-00000-00August fires also break altitude records: fire threatens to raid mountain 'tinderbox'.2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:59:25ZLexisNexisAugust fires also break altitude records: fire threatens to raid mountain 'tinderbox'.


The August fires were not only the most voracious in history, but also broke the record for the number of hectares burned above 1,500 meters of altitude. In the last two decades, never before has so much land burned at such high altitudes as in 2025, which brings us closer to a critical scenario: the possibility of uncontrolled fire penetration into the great reservoirs of forest mass in the mountains.


Why the Zamora-León-Ourense axis became a large fire triangle in just ten days
Experts warn that this rise, brought about by climate change, may dwarf this year's fires compared to what may happen in the future if they move deeper into areas such as the Picos de Europa or attack in the Pyrenees environment.
University of León professor Fernando Castedo and his PhD student Erika García Lima have been the first to compile the data on the rise of fire this year. "The main difference we have seen is that many of these fires have occurred in mountainous areas," Castedo explains to elDiario.es. "We are talking in many cases of more than 1,500 meters of altitude, which are areas less usually hit by fire because there is more humidity and less temperature."
Specifically, 6 of the 13 fires in Castilla y León have an average altitude burned above 1,600 meters, and in four of them areas have burned at altitudes above 2,000 meters. But if we expand the geographical framework, we see that in the rest of the northwestern peninsular there are other high areas that have burned: the fire that went into the Picos de Europa affected shelters and routes located above 2,000 meters, such as Collado Jermoso (2,064 m) and in Galicia has burned Peña Trevinca (2,127 m), the highest peak of this autonomous community.
"What is strange is that we have these large fires, more than 500 hectares, at these altitudes of 1,500-2,000 meters," Castedo stresses. "Climate change is leading us to have dry conditions, even for these areas where these circumstances were not typically given in the vegetation. Fires are increasing in altitude".
A historical circumstance
When we review the historical record and extend the framework to the whole of Spain, we find that in the last 20 years there have been 38 major forest fires at high altitudes above 1,500 meters on average.
In the following map you can see all the large forest fires (over 500 hectares) and the maximum altitude of the areas burned in each fire. The data come from the analysis of 674 large forest fires identified by the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) between 2003 and 2025 crossed with the Digital Terrain Model (DTM) of the National Geographic Institute (IGN). The bar at the top of the graph allows you to change the year to see the historical evolution. And you can expand the information for each fire:
Of the five that have burned the most area, four were in 2025: the A Veiga fire in Ourense (28,000 hectares at 1,650 meters altitude), the León fire of the Picos de Europa (19,000 hectares at 1,607 meters on average), Murias de Paredes in León (5,800 hectares at 1,616m) and Villablino in León (4,300 hectares at 1,634m).
Although the median altitude of the fires has not varied particularly in two decades, the key is in the area burned. That is to say, in 20 years there have not been such large fires burning forest masses at high altitude as there have been this year.
Moreover, many of the fires burned at altitudes above 2,000 meters: of the ten largest fires burning at that altitude since 2003, six were recorded in 2025. In addition to the four mentioned above, the Yeres (León) and Jarilla (Cáceres) fires burned areas above 2,000 meters of altitude. With data from the last 20 years, never before in Spain have so many hectares burned in large forest fires at high altitudes as in 2025.
At the gates of the "powder keg
For Víctor Resco de Dios, professor of forest fires and global change at the University of Lleida, what happened this summer in the northwest peninsular shows that the forecasts that specialists have been making for years are being fulfilled. "The data indicated that the fire belt was going to gain altitude, so it is not surprising," he says.
We are talking in many cases of more than 1,500 meters of altitude, which are areas less usually hit by fire because there is more humidity and lower temperature.
Fernando Castedo - Professor at the University of León
On a global scale, the data are convincing: the area burned in high mountain areas tripled between 2001-2021. In Spain, other studies show that the Fire Weather Index (FWI), an indicator of risk, increases in the higher altitude areas of the peninsula, especially in the Iberian System. "We had also seen it in paleobotanical evidence, which shows how the high mountains burn in warmer periods and are not always safe from fires," says Resco de Dios.
The specialist and his team have recently quantified how much drought and heat are needed to break the "safety margin" of temperature and humidity that protects the Pyrenees. "And the answer is not very encouraging," he notes. "Overall, Pyrenean forests could be on the verge of major change and megafires could reach them with an increase in air temperature of as little as 3°C (30 to 33°C), which is well within the projected increases in this climate change scenario." And, at the rate we are going, this could happen within the next decade or ahead of next season.
"This is what we're up against."
During the VIII Spanish Forestry Congress, held in 2022, the chief inspector of the Support Group of Forestry Actions of the Firefighters of Catalonia (GRAF), Marc Castellnou, launched a call for help to his colleagues in the face of a situation that is about to generate the "perfect storm" in the wooded areas of the Pyrenees. "If we had not closed the Lladurs fire (Lleida) on the night of June 17-18, we would have had to decree a containment perimeter of 106,000 hectares," he said. "Because there was no extinguishing capacity. This is what we are facing, this is the reality".
In a simulation carried out by the Catalan forest firefighters of what would happen in the Pyrenees area if the conditions predicted by climate change in ten years' time were to occur, the result indicated that the fire could devastate more than one and a half million hectares of forest in less than four days.
"The effect of climate change on fires in high mountain ecosystems is already here," stresses Resco de Dios. "And those areas are a powder keg, because they accumulate a lot of biomass, with very lush forests where we can expect absolutely devastating fires," he warns. "We must prepare for a higher frequency of these sixth-generation events in these types of forests."
These mountain areas are a powder keg, with very dense forests where we can expect absolutely devastating fires.
Víctor Resco de Dios - Professor of forest fires and global change at the University of Lleida
One aspect associated with this advance of fire to higher elevations is that it will affect tree species less adapted to flames. "We have seen it in these summer fires in Castilla y León," Fernando Castedo points out. "In the reserve fire that affected the Montaña Palentina Natural Park, leafy species abound, such as beech, sessile oak (Quercus petraea), and in the fires in Villablino, Murias de Paredes or Páramo de Sil there are also mountain species, such as birch and Scots pine, and Las Médulas is an area of chestnut trees." Unlike scrub or resistant species such as Aleppo pine, these species are very vulnerable to fires.
Of the 350,000 hectares that, at the time of writing, 60 fires have burned in 2025, half have burned in areas above 1,000 meters of altitude. If we expand to above 1,500 meters, fires have burned 66,800 hectares. In the previous twenty years, there were never more than 15,000 hectares burned at that altitude. On the contrary, in the areas burned below 1,000 meters in large forest fires we are below the figures of previous years, as can be seen in the following graph:
"It is highly likely that we will see increasingly recurrent fires in forests that are less accustomed to fires," confirms Andrea Duane, a researcher at the University California Davis (UCD). "And this has also been seen in California, in subalpine zones that would be equivalent to those of the Pre-Pyrenees, to make a simile with the peninsula". The specialist recalls that these tree species not adapted to fire recover worse and large areas will be left without a tree layer for a long time. "This could be a great ecological challenge and a new threat to some of our most valuable forests," she says.
This could be a major ecological challenge and a new threat to some of our most valuable forests.
Andrea Duane - Researcher at the University of California Davis (UCD)
In general, many experts agree that non-intervention policies in protected areas have left a reservoir that, under conditions of climate change and in the absence of management, turns mountain areas into a ticking time bomb. "Climate change is going to hold up a dramatic mirror to the situation of our forests, which will reach ever higher levels," warns Marta Corella, vice-dean of the Association of Forestry Engineers.
The 'day after' the mega-fires: we have three months ahead of us to avoid the worst consequences.
In the expert's opinion, the origin goes back to the moment when the headwaters of the river basins ceased to be in the hands of the State and passed to the autonomous communities in the 1980s.The regional administration was more comfortable doing nothing and has prepared the perfect situation for what has happened, which has been nothing more than the staging through climate change of a very vulnerable scenario".

urn:contentItem:6G4F-YN53-RT97-X1MB-00000-00Reports from National Chung Hsing University Advance Knowledge in Forestry (Multi-index remote sensing for post-fire damage assessment: accuracy, carbon loss, and conservation implications)2025-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:59:25ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - FORESTRYReports from National Chung Hsing University Advance Knowledge in Forestry (Multi-index remote sensing for post-fire damage assessment: accuracy, carbon loss, and conservation implications)


2025 JUN 26 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Research findings on forestry are discussed in a new report. According to news originating from Taichung, Taiwan, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "This study advances environmental management practices by developing a comprehensive multi-index remote sensing methodology for rapid and accurate forest fire impact assessment in protected areas. Applied to the 2021 Yushan National Park fire in Taiwan, the approach integrates three complementary vegetation indices-Normalized Burn Ratio (NBR), Burned Area Index (BAI), and Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI)-to evaluate pre-fire and post-fire conditions across forest compartments No."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from National Chung Hsing University: "51 and No. 52. The methodology demonstrates significant advantages for protected area management where recreational activities intersect with conservation priorities. The NBR analysis identified 68.89 hectares of burned area with 97.1% accuracy compared to official reports, establishing the method's reliability for rapid damage assessment. NDVI and BAI analyses provided complementary insights, with NDVI effectively detecting 27.99 hectares of completely destroyed vegetation and BAI identifying 17.80 hectares of severely charred areas, both showing statistical significance when validated against ground observations. Through carbon storage analysis, we quantified a loss ranging from 7 to 18,000 metric tons, demonstrating the approach's capability for environmental impact quantification."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The multi-index methodology reveals varying degrees of burn severity across different forest compartments, enabling precise mapping of ecosystem damage patterns. This framework offers a cost-effective, reproducible approach for both immediate impact evaluation and long-term monitoring of forest recovery, supporting evidence-based management decisions in protected areas globally, though local calibration may be required for optimal performance."
For more information on this research see: Multi-index remote sensing for post-fire damage assessment: accuracy, carbon loss, and conservation implications. Frontiers in Forests and Global Change, 2025,8. (Frontiers in Forests and Global Change - https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/forests-and-global-change#). The publisher for Frontiers in Forests and Global Change is Frontiers Media S.A.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3389/ffgc.2025.1577612.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Chih-Lin Liu, Department of Forestry, National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, Taiwan. Additional authors for this research include You-Ren Wang, Wan-Yu Liu.
Keywords for this news article include: National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, Taiwan, Asia, Conservation, Forestry, Remote Sensing, Science.

urn:contentItem:6FMY-YGW3-RSXH-437S-00000-00Wildfire in New Jersey Pine Barrens expected to grow before it's contained, officials say2025-04-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:59:25ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSSTATE AND REGIONALWildfire in New Jersey Pine Barrens expected to grow before it's contained, officials sayBRUCE SHIPKOWSKIAssociated PressCHATSWORTH, N.J.

CHATSWORTH, N.J. (AP) — A fast-moving wildfire engulfing part of New Jersey's Pine Barrens has not resulted in any injuries, officials said Wednesday, though it's expected to grow before forecast rain later this week.

The fire in southern New Jersey's Lacey and Ocean townships has grown to more than 20 square miles (52 square kilometers) and could continue to burn for days, officials said. No one has been injured so far in the blaze, and 5,000 residents were evacuated but have been permitted to return home. A single commercial building and some vehicles were destroyed in the fire, while 12 structures remained threatened Wednesday evening.

“This is still a very active fire,” said Department of Environmental Protection Commissioner Shawn LaTourette. “As we continue to get this under full control the expectation is that the number of acres will grow and will grow in a place that is unpopulated.”

Officials said the fire is believed to be the second-worst in the last two decades, smaller only than a 2007 blaze that burned 26 square miles (67 square kilometers).

The Garden State Parkway, one of New Jersey's busiest highways, reopened Wednesday morning after officials closed a roughly 7-mile (12-kilometer) stretch in the southern part of the state.

Acting Gov. Tahesha Way declared a state of emergency early Wednesday as officials said they've contained about 50% of the wildfire.

Video released by the state agency overseeing the fire service showed billowing white and black clouds of smoke, intense flames engulfing pines and firefighters dousing a charred structure.

The cause of the fire is still under investigation, authorities said.

Forest fires are a common occurrence in the Pine Barrens, a 1.1 million-acre (445,000-hectare) state and federally protected reserve about the size of the Grand Canyon lying halfway between Philadelphia to the west and the Atlantic coast to the east. The region, with its quick-draining sandy soil, is in peak forest fire season. The trees are still developing leaves, humidity remains low and winds can kick up, drying out the forest floor.

It's a vast wilderness in the country's most densely populated state. LaTourette, the DEP commissioner, said the fire is straddling an area on the edge of wilderness and residential areas.

“It’s the interface where the environment and development meet,” he said.

The area had been under a severe drought until recently, when early spring rains helped dampen the region, but officials cautioned recent low humidity and a dry stretch have heightened the risk of fire.

The Jersey Central Power and Light Company cut power to about 25,000 customers at the request of the Forest Fire Service and the wildfire’s command post Tuesday evening. By late Wednesday afternoon, power had been restored.

On Tuesday, Debi Schaffer was caught in gridlocked traffic after evacuating with her two dogs while her husband agreed to stay with their 22 chickens, The Press of Atlantic City reported.

“I wanted to take them in the car with me; can you imagine 22 chickens in a car?” she told the newspaper.

Around her Waretown house it was “like a war zone,” she said, describing smoke, sirens and the buzz of helicopters.

The site of the fire is near an alpaca farm. The farm said in a Facebook post that the property wasn’t threatened and all of the animals were safe.

The blaze is the second major forest fire in the region in less than a week.

___

Associated Press writers Mike Catalini in Trenton, New Jersey, and Hallie Golden in Seattle contributed to this report.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RRVG-81M1-00000-00Latest fire situation in Spain, live | Meteorology helps to improve the situation of the 18 major active fires2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:59:25ZLexisNexisLatest fire situation in Spain, live | Meteorology helps to improve the situation of the 18 major active fires


EL PAÍS offers free of charge the latest news about the fires. If you want to support our journalism, subscribe.
Improved weather conditions are helping to improve the fire situation in Galicia, Castilla y León and Extremadura, which can now be attacked more effectively. Despite this, there are still about twenty large active fires. The inhabitants of several villages in Zamora have been able to return to their homes after being evicted by the Porto fire, which affects the area around Lake Sanabria. In Galicia, after burning 88,000 hectares, progress is being made in the fight against the fire, although two more fires have been declared in Lugo and Pontevedra. In Extremadura, the Jarilla fire is close to being perimetered after burning 17,000 hectares. A fire has also been declared in S'Albufera, in Mallorca, which has been quickly extinguished.


Go to topNew publicationsEl País
Sánchez travels to Asturias to know the evolution of the fire in Degaña
The President of the Government, Pedro Sánchez, will travel this Friday morning to Asturias to know on the ground the evolution of the forest fire in Degaña, according to government sources. It will be the fourth community affected by the fires that Pedro Sánchez will visit after having been in Galicia, Castilla y León and Extremadura in recent days.
The last visit made by Sánchez to territories affected by the fires was this Tuesday in Molezuelas de la Carballeda (Zamora), although on this occasion he was not accompanied by the president of Castilla y León, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco. That same day, Sánchez also visited the Advanced Command Post of the Jarilla fire (Cáceres) and there he was accompanied by the regional president, María Guardiola.
Last Sunday, he visited in Galicia the areas affected by the fires in the province of Ourense and met with the president of the Xunta, Alfonso Rueda, and with the minister Grande-Marlaska. (EP)
Published at: 08:22 CEST 22/08/2025 El Pais
Nine secondary roads remain closed due to forest fires
Nine secondary roads remain cut this Friday by forest fires, seven in several provinces of Castilla y León, two in Galicia and one in Extremadura, according to the latest information updated by the Directorate General of Traffic (DGT). These are:
Castilla y León
León
LE-2703 in Portilla de la Reina
LE-4212 in Cariseda
LE-5228 in Salas de los Barrios
LE-7311 in Nogar
Zamora
ZA-103 in Vigo de Sanabria
ZA-104 in Vigo de Sanabria
Palencia
P-217 in Cabaño de Abajo
Galicia
Lugo
LU-P-1801 in Arxemil
Extremadura
Cáceres
CC-224 in Hervás
Published at: 08:19 CEST 22/08/2025 and modified at 08:19 CEST 22/08/2025 El País
Castilla y León | Progress in fighting the flames with eight active fires
The progress in the fight against the fire in Zamora and Leon has allowed the return home of the residents of several villages and has gone from 31 to 26 localities evicted. In total, some 1,500 residents are still out of their homes due to the eight large fires that remain active in the Community. The situation has improved in the Porto fire, which affects the natural park of Lake Sanabria, although it is far from being under control with a perimeter of 100 kilometers and numerous hot spots.
In the north of León, the most worrying fire is the one affecting the municipalities of Igüeña and Colinas del Campo de Martín Moro Toledano, which the Junta is investigating whether it was provoked or accidentally caused by a machine working on the extinguishing of the Fasgar fire. There is also concern about the Anllares del Sil fire, where one of the outbreaks has been reactivated.
Published at: 08:14 CEST 22/08/2025 El País
Galicia | The situation improves in Ourense, but seven major fires remain active
The night has been quiet in the province of Ourense, where the five major fires have not gone to more. However, five large fires remain active in the province (Chandrexa de Queixa and Vilariño (19,000 hectares), Oímbra and Xinzo de Limia (17,000), A Mezquita-A Esculqueira (10,000), Larouco-Seadur (30,000) and Carballeda de Valdeorras-Casaio (2,600)). Situation 2 remains at provincial level.
To these fires are added the two declared yesterday in Oia and Vilaboa (Pontevedra), also level 2 because of its proximity to population centers. Both exceed 20 hectares, according to the Xunta de Galicia, and have forced the evacuation of 45 people from a campsite and another 14 from their homes.
There are no evacuated populations or confinements.
Published at: 08:03 CEST 22/08/2025 El País
forest fires
The emergency services face a new day with 20 serious fires active, but the weather is in their favor.
María Martín
Emergency services face a new day of firefighting with more favorable forecasts after two weeks of setbacks. The last hours have brought a respite with lower temperatures and rain has begun to fall on some territories. Galicia, Castilla y León, Asturias and Extremadura, which accumulate more than twenty active fires, finally have the weather on their side. The AEMET confirmed that the forecasts for the next few hours in the affected regions will play in favor of the firefighting teams. But the relief does not erase the magnitude of the tragedy: since last August 12, when the pre-emergency was activated, more than 33,000 people have had to leave their homes and more than 403,000 hectares have burned throughout the country. This is the worst fire year since 2006, according to the European Copernicus system. At the close of this Thursday, 20 fires considered of maximum severity are still active.

The agricultural and livestock sector is in agony due to the virulence of the flames and the burning of thousands of hectares -more than 350,000, according to the Copernicus satellite surveillance system- that are increasing every day the economic impact of the fires this August. Galicia | Evicted dozens of people by two new fires in Pontevedra and one in Lugo
Three new fires have been declared in the last hours in Galicia, two in the province of Pontevedra and one in Lugo, which join those that for days punish the province of Ourense, where they have burned in just two weeks more than 82,000 hectares. The one affecting the Pontevedra municipality of Oia has forced the evacuation of a campsite, while the one burning in Vilaboa has forced the evacuation of 14 people. Both have been declared level 2, the maximum, as has the one declared in the municipality of Carballedo in Lugo.
The two fires in Pontevedra started this Thursday afternoon. In the case of Oia, they have had to evict 45 people from a campsite located in Mougás, as reported by 112 Galicia. Meanwhile, in the fire of Santa Cristina de Cobres, in Vilaboa, 14 people have been evicted from the place of Paradellas. Rural Environment has also reported that it has been necessary to declare the situation 2 in a fire that has been declared in the municipality of Carballedo, parish of Cova, due to its proximity to the core of Oleiros.
In addition to these three fires, Galicia remains at level 2 throughout the province of Ourense, where the five active fires that cover more land, about 80,000 hectares according to the latest estimates of the Xunta are concentrated. (EFE)

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RRVG-80W0-00000-00This is what the forest of the future must look like so that Europe does not burn down2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:59:25ZLexisNexisThis is what the forest of the future must look like so that Europe does not burn down


It is necessary to imagine half a million soccer fields in flames to understand the magnitude of the fires that hit Spain in 2025. A year in which 373,000 hectares of Spanish territory have burned, according to Copernicus data. Especially in the provinces of León, Orense and Zamora. "Full solidarity with Spain, hit by the mega fire of the century," wrote the French president, Emmanuel Macron, on August 19, on his X account.


France has also suffered this summer from what is considered the country's worst fire in 70 years. In just 48 hours, the flames of the Aude fire in the south of the country devoured some 17,000 hectares, an area larger than 144 times Madrid's Retiro Park. The fire caught a 65-year-old woman, who died in her charred home in Saint-Laurent-de-la-Cabrerisse, in "a catastrophe on an unprecedented scale," as French Prime Minister François Bayrou called it. Authorities have banned access to the forest until August 25.
"We are facing a combination of meteorological and climatic factors, with heat waves and a precipitation deficit," Christophe Chantepy, an expert in Forest Fire Protection atFrance's National Forest Organization (ONF), explains to El Confidencial. Chantepy explains that the vegetation is very dry "and becomes very flammable", and, "if we add to this another factor, which is the wind, a spark is enough to cause very large areas to burn, as we are experiencing right now in Spain or Portugal, and we have also experienced in France," he adds.
And in Italy, where there have been more than 700 fires in the first seven months of the year, which have devastated more than 320 km², the equivalent of three times the city of Florence. A situation similar to that in Greece, where after a certain lull the last few summers, thanks to more moderate weather and rapid firefighting deployments since the devastating fires of 2021, which scorched 173,000 hectares and left 20 dead, the downward trend seems to be reversed this year. In mid-August, in just 48 hours, 10,000 hectares burned in fast-spreading fires in Chios, Zante, Achaea, Preveza and Keratea, according to the National Observatory of Athens.
Some 39% of the European Union's land area is forest, or some 160 million hectares, according to European Commission data. With an increasingly dry and hot climate: should we get used to destructive fires every summer? "No, because things can be done," says Chantepy, who explains that, unlike floods, "fires do not start by themselves".
"In most cases it starts by human action: by a spark, a cigarette butt, a piece of machinery, a barbecue... and sometimes also voluntarily," he warns. Some 96% of the fires in the EU where the cause is known - half of them - are due to human actions, whether negligent or deliberate, and only 4% are due to natural causes such as lightning, according to a study by the Joint Research Center (JRC). So, "we have the ability to reduce the number of outbreaks," says Chantepy.
At the same time, we can limit the intensity of the fire, Chantepy continues, and "that implies territorial planning: opening access routes for firefighters, having water points and clearing, i.e. removing part of the vegetation near the places where the fire can be more destructive or where it can start". In France, for example, he says, it is mandatory to clear brush around homes and on both sides of roads.
"In French, we call it the 'culture of risk,'" Chantepy points out, "people must understand that they live with the risk of wildfires, which is increasing. He says it is crucial to be alert and regulations are needed to limit construction in high-risk areas and ensure proper land management.
The forest of the future to keep Europe from burning.
"Almost everywhere in the world, the focus is on expanding firefighting capacity and, that means always going after the problem," criticizes German forester Johann Goldammer, director of the Global Fire Monitoring Center (GFMC) and one of the people who knows the most about fires. In an interview with Der Standard, Goldammer explains that fires "can be prevented. And to do that, one has to ask "how we can design our landscapes to be less vulnerable to fire." "We have to ask ourselves what the forest of the future should look like," he says.
The expert specifies that the forest of the future must be "a forest that can live in a climate like the one we already have in North Africa". For this, "the ideal is agroforestry: a combination of agriculture and grazing with forest. Since, if part of the land is cultivated, there will not be as much combustible material as in a densely populated forest. "Also, goats and sheep can constantly reduce the fuel material," he adds.
There are several reasons why the Mediterranean region is so prone to fires, Goldammer explains, and part of it has to do with the landscape being changed. In Turkey, for example, one reason is large-scale reforestation, "with pine plantations that are extremely flammable". Added to this is that, traditionally, the Mediterranean has been densely populated, but that has changed.
"Young people are leaving the countryside for the cities and there is no one left to work the land," Goldammer continues. Instead, he says, they reforest or simply, the land lies fallow and then, ecological succession occurs: "Nature reclaims the space, which means that fire finds fuel because there is a lot of wood." "So the rural exodus favors forest fires, and to this we add climate change," he qualifies.
Forestry policy is the responsibility of each EU member state. Against a short-term cycle of "putting out fires", "it is important to favor preventive activities", says a recent audit by the European Court of Auditors, which criticizes that the authorities"have not taken the opportunity to improve the impact of EU funding" and notes that there is "little information on the results of EU-funded projects and their long-term sustainability" as well as "shortcomings in the selection of projects".
Herbivores, planning and agroforestry
More and more research is advocating the role of large herbivores in reducing the type of vegetation that increases fire risk, a concept known as "rewilding". Projects that advocate rewilding are betting on three approaches: first, introducing or eliminating certain animals in a controlled manner to recover native plants; second, they may use prescribed burning to reduce the risk of fire; and third, facilitating the connection between habitats, "such as a natural park with agricultural areas to facilitate seed dispersal," explains the CREAF research center.
Similar so-called "renaturalization" efforts are also underway in southeastern Bulgariathrough the 'From Iron Curtain to Green Belt' project that aims to replace flammable non-native conifer plantations with more resilient deciduous species and establish 100-meter firebreaks to interrupt fuel continuity.
More area burned but fewer deaths
Encouragingly, despite the increase in burned area, fatalities have decreased, "possibly a sign that rapid evacuations, public warnings and lessons from past disasters are bearing fruit," Marina Gavrilaki, EU Climate Pact Ambassador for Greece and co-founder of the startup Physisorg, explains in conversation with OBCT/El Confidencial. However, she stresses that the ecological impact remains serious: "More than 55% of the burned areas are within Natura 2000 sites," she adds.
The situation is complex, "and must be addressed at that level of complexity, because sometimes punctual solutions or superficial analyses are given," warns Giulia Casamento, head of Biodiversity and Ceas at Legambiente Sicilia, who believes that, in turn, there is an underlying cultural problem: "the seriousness of fires is underestimated, especially in the agricultural field" and "they are not adequately sanctioned."
Cork oaks and holm oaks in Portugal
Ecosystem restoration and nature-based forest management; landscape planning; protection of wetlands, peatlands and mountain forests; and rewetting of peatlands - when they dry out, they become highly flammable - are some of WWF and BirdLife' s recommendations to prevent fires. Another recommendation involves replacing exotic species of flammable trees with more resistant native species, something that is being implemented in some European countries. For example, in the Portuguese municipality ofAlenquer, Aleppo pines are being replaced by cork oaks and holm oaks.
But transforming a landscape takes time and resources: "It takes many years, sometimes even decades," warns Goldammer. And, "that's a difficult task for politicians," he concludes.
One has to imagine half a million soccer fields in flames to understand the magnitude of the fires raging in Spain in 2025. A year in which 373,000 hectares of Spanish territory burned, according to Copernicus data. Especially in the provinces of León, Orense and Zamora. "Full solidarity with Spain, hit by the mega fire of the century," wrote the French president, Emmanuel Macron, on August 19, on his X account.

April 23rd, 2025 ( Axios - Delivered by Newstex )

A rapidly growing wildfire in the Pine Barrens area of southern New Jersey prompted evacuation orders for about 3,000 people and shut down parts of a major highway in the state for hours on Tuesday.

The big picture: The Jones Road Forest Fire was burning across some 8,500 acres at 10% containment just before 11pm ET, some nine hours after the New Jersey Forest Fire Service announced its ignition in dry, windy conditions near Barnegat Township in Ocean County.

Fire Operations Update:The evacuation orders will remain in effect throughout the night .Route 9 will remain closed...

Posted by Lacey Township PD on Tuesday, April 22, 2025

Threat level: Residents in Ocean and Lacey Townships were under evacuation orders, but there were no immediate reports of injuries.

The fire was threatening around 1,320 structures, per a fire service post to X late Tuesday.

The Garden State Parkway, which runs north and south through N.J., was shut for several hours between exits 63 and 80 and traffic was diverted elsewhere, officials said.

More than 25,000 customers in Ocean County were without power early Wednesday, per utility tracker poweroutage.us.

Context: The wildfire ignited when fire risk was high in a region that U.S. Drought Monitor data shows is experiencing abnormally dry to severe drought.

Research shows climate change is the main driver behind increased wildfire risk and it's increasing the odds and severity of droughts.

What we're watching: Temperatures cooled somewhat and winds were forecast to diminish overnight, the National Weather Service's Mount Holly, N.J., office said on X.

"The theme of above normal temperatures will continue through the end of the week, with highs in the 70s to near 80 (60s for the coast)," it said. "Next chance of showers/storms arrives Friday night & Saturday."

Screenshot: Red Cross New Jersey/X

urn:contentItem:6FMS-CRR3-RRPM-73SX-00000-00Jones Wildfire Update: Officials Respond to Closed Nuclear Power Plant Risk2025-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:59:25ZLexisNexisJones Wildfire Update: Officials Respond to Closed Nuclear Power Plant RiskJoe Edwards

A wildfire in Ocean County has scorched over 8,500 acres and forced evacuations near a decommissioned nuclear plant, which still holds spent fuel.

A wildfire in Ocean County, New Jersey, has officials closely monitoring the decommissioned Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station in Lacey Township.

The Jones Road Forest Fire, advancing near the plant that still houses spent fuel, has led to evacuations and triggered round-the-clock oversight.

The Context

The proximity of a raging wildfire to a nuclear-related site, albeit decommissioned, raises safety and infrastructure concerns. Officials have said that even if a fire did reach where spent nuclear fuel is stored, there would be no danger.

The fire has already prompted the closure of some major highways and the evacuation of several thousand people.

What To Know

The wildfire, which has scorched over 8,500 acres, was only 10 percent contained as of Wednesday morning and evacuation orders had displaced approximately 3,000 residents, according to fire officials and local reports.

Authorities reported that major highways, including portions of Route 9 and the Garden State Parkway, were closed due to the fire in Ocean County.

The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station is being monitored round the clock by security personnel, Patrick O'Brien, a spokesperson for Holtec, the company that owns the property, told NJ Advance Media.

The site was closed in 2018 but still contains "spent fuel."

"Spent fuel is still on-site, as with every nuclear plant in the country, but it is in harden(ed) cask systems that are built to withstand these types of extreme scenarios, including fire," O'Brien said.

He said that on Tuesday embers from the fire were carried by the wind onto a small patch of grass located on the power plant's property, north of its buildings and structures.

The fire near the nuclear facility was "completely and safely extinguished," according to O'Brien.

According to O'Brien and Shawn M. LaTourette, Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, even if flames were to reach the area where spent nuclear fuel is stored in secure casks, there would be no danger.

O'Brien emphasized that all buildings at the Oyster Creek site are built to endure fires, while Mr. LaTourette added, "There is no threat to the security of the material in cask storage. Dry cask systems are engineered to withstand temperatures far beyond those of a wildfire."

Local police have also warned residents about potential prolonged outages as utilities pre-emptively cut power to minimize risks.

According to PowerOutage.us, a service that tracks disruptions, some 25,500 customers were without power across the state as of Wednesday morning.

What People Are Saying

Patrick O'Brien, a spokesman for Holtec, said: "Oyster Creek Security Personnel are keeping careful round-the-clock watch on all of the site property to ensure protection from the current forest fire in Waretown."

Lacey Township Police Department said on Facebook, Tuesday: "The evacuation orders will remain in effect throughout the night. Route 9 will remain closed for the foreseeable future as fire crews continue to work in that area. Traffic will be diverted through Route 539....

"Power is expected to remain out with no timetable for return."

Barnegat Police Department said on Facebook, Tuesday: "We continue to monitor progress from the command post. The fire has generally moved out of our area and firefighters are working diligently to extinguish any remaining pockets.

"The town remains without power and we ask that everyone please be patient and use extra caution throughout the night and as we head out in the morning."

What Happens Next

An update on the situation from the New Jersey Forest Fire Service is expected at 11 a.m. Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:6FMS-9H63-RSMN-S1WT-00000-00Wildfire in New Jersey Pine Barrens expected to grow before it's contained, officials say2025-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:59:25ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSSTATE AND REGIONALWildfire in New Jersey Pine Barrens expected to grow before it's contained, officials sayBRUCE SHIPKOWSKIAssociated PressCHATSWORTH, N.J.

CHATSWORTH, N.J. — A fast-moving wildfire engulfing part of New Jersey's Pine Barrens has not resulted in any injuries, officials said Wednesday, though it's expected to grow before forecast rain later this week.

The fire in southern New Jersey's Lacey and Ocean townships has grown to more than 20 square miles and could continue to burn for days, officials said. No one has been injured so far in the blaze, and 5,000 residents were evacuated but have been permitted to return home. A single commercial building and some vehicles were destroyed in the fire, while 12 structures remained threatened Wednesday evening.

“This is still a very active fire,” said Department of Environmental Protection Commissioner Shawn LaTourette. “As we continue to get this under full control the expectation is that the number of acres will grow and will grow in a place that is unpopulated.”

Officials said the fire is believed to be the second-worst in the last two decades, smaller only than a 2007 blaze that burned 26 square miles (67 square kilometers).

The Garden State Parkway, one of New Jersey's busiest highways, reopened Wednesday morning after officials closed a roughly 7-mile (12-kilometer) stretch in the southern part of the state.

Acting Gov. Tahesha Way declared a state of emergency early Wednesday as officials said they've contained about 50% of the wildfire.

Video released by the state agency overseeing the fire service showed billowing white and black clouds of smoke, intense flames engulfing pines and firefighters dousing a charred structure.

The cause of the fire is still under investigation, authorities said.

Forest fires are a common occurrence in the Pine Barrens, a 1.1 million-acre (445,000-hectare) state and federally protected reserve about the size of the Grand Canyon lying halfway between Philadelphia to the west and the Atlantic coast to the east. The region, with its quick-draining sandy soil, is in peak forest fire season. The trees are still developing leaves, humidity remains low and winds can kick up, drying out the forest floor.

It's a vast wilderness in the country's most densely populated state. LaTourette, the DEP commissioner, said the fire is straddling an area on the edge of wilderness and residential areas.

“It’s the interface where the environment and development meet,” he said.

The area had been under a severe drought until recently, when early spring rains helped dampen the region, but officials cautioned recent low humidity and a dry stretch have heightened the risk of fire.

The Jersey Central Power and Light Company cut power to about 25,000 customers at the request of the Forest Fire Service and the wildfire’s command post Tuesday evening. By late Wednesday afternoon, power had been restored.

On Tuesday, Debi Schaffer was caught in gridlocked traffic after evacuating with her two dogs while her husband agreed to stay with their 22 chickens, The Press of Atlantic City reported.

“I wanted to take them in the car with me; can you imagine 22 chickens in a car?” she told the newspaper.

Around her Waretown house it was “like a war zone,” she said, describing smoke, sirens and the buzz of helicopters.

The site of the fire is near an alpaca farm. The farm said in a Facebook post that the property wasn’t threatened and all of the animals were safe.

The blaze is the second major forest fire in the region in less than a week.

___

Associated Press writers Mike Catalini in Trenton, New Jersey, and Hallie Golden in Seattle contributed to this report.
